Comment: Basra.   That is the coastal development.   Until modern dams Basra had a lake estuary at the outlet of both the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. It was a major trading port only slightly up a river not unlike London or Hamburg.   But then dams started changing the waterflow and boats got a lot bigger. The lake that used to exist dried up with only a small canal and river still existing. Modern cargo boats can't navigate into Basra as it is easily, and so most port facilities moved onto the actual coast with the ocean. And that's without counting the last 50 years as Turkey has been damning up the Tigris and Euphrates before they ever reach Iraq and using the water for their own agriculture. Iraq now gets only about 30% the water they were getting a century ago, though some of that is probably also related to climate change.
